PROP_MULTI_THREAD_OUTPUT

public static final java.lang.String PROP_MULTI_THREAD_OUTPUT
Property controls multi thread output when running with one thread. Multi thread output prints output from builds one line at a time so messages are not badly interleaved
Default (off)

PROP_LONG_FILE_NAMES

public static final java.lang.String PROP_LONG_FILE_NAMES
This property if set to "on" will cause the java compiler to use absolute paths. This is more ant like so some IDE's can parse the output and link to the files when errors occure.

Method Detail

getCurrentTablesaw

public static Tablesaw getCurrentTablesaw()
Returns the current instance of Tablesaw from off of the thread local data. This is provided as an easy mechanism for accessing the current make instance from within the build script

printErr

public static void printErr(java.lang.String msg)

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
Creates an instance of Tablesaw and process the targets on the command line. The options main takes are:
-v Verbose mode. This will echo every command passed to exec and every file copy
-f Build file. If no file is specified "build.bsh" is the default.
-t Number of threads to use. This is the number of threads to use when building a target.
After the options are the list of targets to build.

Property files. Tablesaw loads properties from three locations and makes them available to the script via the getProperty methods. First the system properties are read. Second a tablesaw.properties file is read if it exists. Third an env.properties file is read if it exists. In order to gain access to the environment variables the last properties file is used. To use this file you will need to echo the environment to this file before calling Tablesaw.
An example of this would be to write a script as follows
(windows)
set > env.properties
java -jar tablesaw.jar
 or
(linux)
env > env.properties
java -jar tablesaw.jar
 Then for neetness tablesaw will delete the env.properties file when it is done.

Properties that effect tablesaw
(note the underscore versions are for linux envoronment variable compatibility)
tablesaw.threadCount or tablesaw_threadCount - Setting this property will tell tablesaw the number of threads to use while building a target.

buildTarget

public void buildTarget(java.lang.String target)
                 throws TablesawException
Processes the rule for the given target. Before the build queue is generated for the specified target an attempt is made to call a script function that matches the following signiture
void prepForTarget(String target);

This allows the script to set up any special varaibles for the target.

Parameters:
target - Target to be built.
Throws:
TablesawException

buildDefaultTarget

public void buildDefaultTarget()
                        throws TablesawException
Builds the default target. setDefaultTarget Must have been called within the build script for this method to work.

Throws:
TablesawException

buildTarget

public void buildTarget(java.lang.String target,
                        boolean prep)
                 throws TablesawException
Processes the rule for the given target. Before the build queue is generated for the specified target an attempt is made to call a script function that matches the following signiture
void prepForTarget(String target);

This allows the script to set up any special varaibles for the target.

Parameters:
target - Target to be built.
prep - If true prepForTarget is called otherwise it is not
Throws:
TablesawException

locateFileUsingRules

public CachedFile locateFileUsingRules(java.lang.String file)
Tries to locate a file by looking in the search paths. This method also check the rules to see if the file can be created, if so a file object is returned with the path to where the file would be based on the rule.

Parameters:
file - The file name to look for.
Returns:
The file object or null if none is found.

fixPath

public static java.lang.String fixPath(java.lang.String path)
Fixes the directory seperators for the current platform. It is encuraged to use only forward slashes in make files and then call this function when the path will be handed to a platform specific call.

Parameters:
path - Path to be checked for correct seperators
Returns:
The path with the directory sperators appropriat for the platform.

                java.lang.String logFile)
         throws TablesawException
Executes a command and waits until it is finnished. Executes a command and then pipes the stdin and stdout of the process to System.in and System.out.

Parameters:
cmd - command line of the process to start.
exitOnError - If the process reutrns an error the make will stop.
logFile - Output is sent to this log file as well
Returns:
process exit code
Throws:
TablesawException
Since:
1.0.0

exec

public int exec(java.lang.String cwd,
                java.lang.String cmd,
                boolean exitOnError)
         throws TablesawException
Executes a command and waits until it is finnished. Executes a command and then pipes the stdin and stdout of the process to System.in and System.out. Passing in a current working directory requires the path in cmd to be the absolute path. You can use the fullPath method to aid in retrieving the absolute path.

Parameters:
cwd - Sets the current working directory of the process.
cmd - command line of the process to start.
exitOnError - If the process reutrns an error the make will stop.
Returns:
process exit code
Throws:
TablesawException

exec

public int exec(java.lang.String cwd,
                java.lang.String cmd,
                boolean exitOnError,
                java.lang.String logFile,
                java.lang.String redirect)
         throws TablesawException
Executes a command and waits until it is finnished. Executes a command and then pipes the stdin and stdout of the process to System.in and System.out. Passing in a current working directory requires the path in cmd to be the absolute path. You can use the fullPath method to aid in retrieving the absolute path.

Parameters:
cwd - Sets the current working directory of the process. My be null.
cmd - command line of the process to start.
exitOnError - If the process reutrns an error the make will stop.
logFile - Output is sent to this log file as well. May be null.
redirect - File to redirect output to. May be null.
Returns:
process exit code
Throws:
TablesawException

                boolean exitOnError,

         throws TablesawException

Passing in a current working directory requires the path in cmd to be the absolute path. You can use the fullPath method to aid in retrieving the absolute path.

Parameters:
cwd - Sets the current working directory of the process. My be null.
cmdArr - command line of the process to start.
exitOnError - If the process reutrns an error the make will stop.
logFile - Output is sent to this log file as well. May be null.
redirect - File to redirect output to. May be null.
Returns:
process exit code
Throws:
TablesawException
Since:
1.0.0

copyIfNewer

public int copyIfNewer(java.lang.String sourceDir,
                       java.lang.String[] fileList,
                       java.lang.String dest)
                throws TablesawException
Copies files specified in fileList parameter from the source directory to the destination directory. Files will retain relative paths when copied. This means that if the source directory were "src" and the destination were "build" and the file list contained {"tablesaw/file1", "tablesaw/file2"} the files src/tablesaw/file1 and
src/tablesaw/file2
will be copied to
build/tablesaw/file1 and
build/tablesaw/file2
And the files will only be copied if they are newer then the destination. Also the directories will be created automatically. It is good to use this with the output from createFileList to copy files.

Parameters:
sourceDir - Source directory
fileList - List of files to copy.
dest - Destination directory.
Throws:
TablesawException
Since:
1.0.0

copyIfNewer

public int copyIfNewer(java.lang.String sourceDir,
                       java.util.List<java.lang.String> fileList,
                       java.lang.String dest)
                throws TablesawException
Throws:
TablesawException

copyIfNewer

public int copyIfNewer(java.lang.String[] fileList,
                       java.lang.String dest)
                throws TablesawException
Copies a list of files to the destination directory. File lists can be created using createFileList and then passed to this method. All of the files in the list will end up in the destination directory.

Parameters:
fileList - List of files to copy
dest - Destination directory to copy files to.
Throws:
TablesawException
Since:
1.0.0

copy

public void copy(java.lang.String sourceDir,
                 java.lang.String filePattern,
                 java.lang.String dest)
Copies all files in the source directory that match the file pattern to the destination directory.

Parameters:
sourceDir - Source directory.
filePattern - Regex file pattern.
dest - Destination directory to copy files to.

copy

public void copy(java.lang.String source,
                 java.lang.String dest)
Performs a file copy. The file denoted by source is copied to dest. dest can either be a file name or a directory. The directory structure in the destination will be created automatically. This will not work if the destination is the directory to copy to and it does not exist.

processMakeDependencyFiles

public void processMakeDependencyFiles(java.lang.String[] files,
                                       boolean create,
                                       boolean soft)
                                throws TablesawException
Reads a list of GNU style dependency files and adds them to the Tablesaw dependency list. If a file does not exist and create is set to true Tablesaw will try and find a rule to build the file.

Parameters:
files - List of GNU style dependency files.
create - Attempst to create the file if it does not exist
soft - Tells Tablesaw that the dependencies in this file are to be treated as soft meaning if the file does not exist do not try to build it.
Throws:
TablesawException

processMakeDependencyFile

public void processMakeDependencyFile(java.lang.String file,
                                      boolean create,
                                      boolean soft)
                               throws TablesawException
Reads a GNU make file and addes the dependencies to the build. If the file does not exist and create is set to true Tablesaw will try and find a rule to build this file.

Parameters:
file - GNU make dependency file to include
create - Attempt to create the file if it does not exist
soft - Tells Tablesaw that the dependencies in this file are to be treated as soft meaning if the file does not exist do not try to build it.
Throws:
TablesawException

substitute

                                                          java.lang.String destPattern,
                                                          java.util.List<java.lang.String> srcList)

substitute

public static java.lang.String[] substitute(java.lang.String srcPattern,
                                            java.lang.String destPattern,
                                            java.lang.String[] srcList)
Perform pattern substitution on the srcList String array. This method goes through each String in srcList and calls replaceAll on the string using srcPattern and destPattern as arguments.

Parameters:
srcPattern - Regular expression search pattern.
destPattern - Replacement pattern.
srcList - Array of strings to perform pattern substitution on.
Returns:
New string array containing the substituted strings

file

public java.io.File file(java.lang.String file)
This returns a File object for the given file path. The file path specified must be relatvie to the build file in which the call is being made, which may not be the current working directory. This is useful for build files that are being ran in directories other then the one where Tablesaw is originaly called from. For example if Tablesaw is called from the work directory and the build file specified is proj/build.bsh, Tablesaw internaly will set the working directory as /work/proj and all file paths will be relative to there. If in the build script you wish to open your own file handle and call new File("f1"); The File object returned will point at /work/f1 not /work/proj/f1. By calling getRelativeFile("f1") in this case will return a File object pointing to /work/proj/f1

Parameters:
file - Path to the file. This path is relative to the build script.
Returns:
A file object pointing to the file specified.
Since:
1.0.0

printf

public java.lang.String printf(java.lang.String formatStr,
                               java.lang.Object[] args)
Formats a string similar to the standard library API "printf". Supported flags are d, f, x, X and s. It suports left and right alignment padding and precision.

Parameters:
formatStr - Formated string similar to the standard library API printf.
args - Array of objects to put into the formated string.
Since:
1.0.0
